metadata.case_name: Appellants (Hindu Undivided Families) v. Wealth Tax Officer

facts.text: The respective appellants in these appeals who constitute Hindu undivided families were charged under s. 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957.
The writ petitions filed by these appellants were heard by a Special Bench of the Allahabad High Court consisting of Gurtu, Upadhya, and Jagdish Sahai, JJ.
Gurtu and Jagdish Sahai, JJ. rejected the appellants' contention and upheld the validity of s.3; Upadhya, J. held it ultra vires.
In accordance with the majority decision, the writ petitions (Civil Misc. Writs Nos. 2127, 2128 and 2980 to 2983 of 1959) were dismissed.
The appellants obtained certificates from the High Court and appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Act was passed in 1957 to provide for the levy of wealth tax. Section 3 provides for charging wealth-tax on net wealth of every individual, Hindu undivided family and company.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 in so far as it purports to levy a charge of wealth tax in respect of the net wealth of a Hindu undivided family at the specified rate, is valid.

petitioner_arguments.text: The word 'individuals' used in Entry 86 List I cannot take in Hindu undivided families as they are groups of individuals, not individuals, and companies.
If outside Entry 86, cannot be under Entry 97 as wealth tax is specifically in Entry 86, nor under Art. 248 read with Entry 97.
Contrast with Entry 82 (unlimited) and separate mention of companies limits 'individuals' to natural persons, not groups; legislative history of Income-tax Acts distinguishes individuals from HUFs.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 82 List I; Income-tax Act 1922 s.3; Act II of 1886 ss.3,5

respondent_arguments.text: The word 'individuals' in Entry 86 is wide enough to take within its sweep groups of individuals such as Hindu undivided families.
Alternatively, Entry 97 residuary entry covers it as matter not enumerated in List II or III.

court_reasoning.text: Words in Entries must receive widest interpretation; no narrow sense; general words extend to ancillary matters.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gwyer C.J. in United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum

court_reasoning.text: No limitation by contrasting Entries or legislative history; Entry 86 specifies assessees as precaution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Individuals includes groups owning assets together like HUFs

court_reasoning.text: Impossible to assume Constitution excluded HUFs; shares fluctuate but legislature decides levy method.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Groups of individuals forming unit covered

court_reasoning.text: Legislative history of tax Acts irrelevant for constitutional Entries; cf. income including capital gains.
High Courts consensus upholds; individual includes group forming unit (Sodra Devi).

holdings.text: Section 3 valid as Parliament competent under Entry 86 List I to levy wealth tax on HUFs.

outcome.summary: The appeals are dismissed as the Supreme Court upholds the validity of s.3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 for levying wealth tax on Hindu undivided families under Entry 86 List I of the Seventh Schedule.

key_quotes.text: the relevant words used in the Entries of the Seventh Schedule must receive the widest interpretation.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: it is impossible to assume that while thinking of levying taxes on the capital value of assets, Hindu undivided families could possibly have been intended to be left out.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects exclusion of HUFs from Entry 86

key_quotes.text: the word individual is narrower than the word Assessee, it does not mean only a human being, but is wide enough to include a group of persons forming a unit.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Sodra Devi; supports broad meaning
